stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the level design and visual theming for a mine area in Course 12. His focus was on restructuring the level's flow, adding platforming elements like a wooden bridge, and creating assets like a fireplace for a 'Goomba bandit' hideout. He also debugged technical issues, discussed his game design philosophies, and interacted with his team and community in the chat.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working on Course 12, a mine-themed level, which he significantly restructured because he felt the previous layout was 'not very good'.
A Wild West-style interactive cutscene is planned for Course 12, featuring a quick-time event shootout against the character Boshi.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna have a Boshi. And he's gonna make a shootout with you and we're gonna have a cutscene here. Where you're just sitting on top of here and it's like the Wild West thing. And there's gonna be a countdown and you have to press B before he does to kill him.

development_findings.summary: The mine area will serve as a hideout for a 'Goomba gang' using cork guns, and will feature minecart ride sections as a core mechanic.
development_findings.quote: The idea will be, this will be the Goomba gang's hideout. So there's gonna be Goombas with Korg guns around. They're gonna have a little camp over there. And the rest is kind of like crazy mine cart stuff.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses an alphabetical naming convention for 3D models as a practical method to control render order and optimize performance through Z-sorting.
development_findings.quote: I have it named that way because the export order of the meshes is by alphabet so if I name it that way I can guarantee it will be rendered first on the level and you want to Z sort your geometry.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a private, unreleased version of the Project64 emulator called 'Project 64 Legacy' to overcome the stability and accuracy issues of older public builds while retaining a familiar UI.
development_findings.quote: I am using a private, in-development version of Project64 called 'Project 64 Legacy' which uses the 1.6 UI but has better performance, accuracy, and audio.

development_findings.summary: Kaze accepted a technical suggestion from a viewer to optimize the collision system by replacing linked lists with arrays that are formed on level boot.
development_findings.quote: Your idea sounds sensible... maybe there should just be arrays formed when the level boots... I'll note that... that's a good idea.

development_findings.summary: The level design is inspired by Wario's Gold Mine from Mario Kart 64 and the cave from Tiny-Huge Island in Super Mario 64.
Kaze believes the life system is an outdated mechanic for a game like Mario 64 and has implemented 'bootless' stars for red coin collection, which don't exit the player from the level.
development_findings.quote: Lives don't make sense in a game like Mario 64. Let's all be honest. There should not be lives in Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process involves first creating the geometry and ensuring good player flow, then adding visual details and theming like lighting and props afterwards.

Kaze demonstrated his asset creation pipeline by taking a high-poly fireplace model from an online source, decimating it for N64 performance, re-doing the UVs to fix texture mapping issues, and implementing it with custom lighting.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values new concepts and ideas in games over polish, citing Mario Odyssey as an example of a game that felt polished but lacked substantive new experiences.
context_findings.quote: What I look for in games is like new concepts, new ideas, stuff like that. And Mario Odyssey kind of felt like a very polished experience, but a lot of the stuff that is to experience barely felt worth experiencing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explicitly identifies his target audience as hardcore, long-time fans of 3D Mario games, contrasting his project with Nintendo's mass-market approach.
context_findings.quote: For like, a weird nerd that's been playing Nintendo games in his basement for 25 years, my game is definitely going to be way better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes traditional boss fights, especially those that involve waiting. He prefers bosses that serve as atmospheric set pieces with continuous, freeform gameplay, citing Ocarina of Time's Gohma as a positive example of aesthetic over complex mechanics.
context_findings.quote: Boss fights are my least favorite part of any game. I think I can only enjoy bosses as set pieces.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes a goal-oriented and intense personality, applying it to his personal fitness goals where he pushes himself to the point of injury due to impatience and ego.
context_findings.quote: I'm bad at cuts cuz I get impatient and then I cut way too hard and I lose weight so fast that like I am getting injured. I also have too much ego so I don't lower the weight while I'm dieting like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze observes that companies can leverage the internet's short attention span to make and then quietly reverse controversial changes without long-term backlash.
context_findings.quote: The Internet's attention span collectively is very small so you can kind of just do a thing to appease the Internet and then undo the thing two months later and no one's gonna say anything.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with unsolicited and unhelpful technical advice from the community, particularly regarding which emulator to use for his specific development needs.
context_findings.quote: I am a little bit on edge about people recommending me emulators. Because people recommend me the same free emulators over and over that don't fucking work for me. And it is getting so annoying.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for the final visual polish and 'rework' of levels after Kaze completes the initial geometry and design.
biobak.quote: You're already looking forward to the Biobak rework? It's not even done yet. But it's true. The Biobak rework is going to make the force instantly much better.

biobak.summary: Biobak has significant creative freedom to change or replace assets, such as the fireplace Kaze created, during the final art pass.
biobak.quote: There's also a good chance that during the reworking, Biobak is just gonna remove this and put his own thing.

biobak.summary: Biobak was actively watching the development stream live from a train station, indicating his engagement with the project even while traveling.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the stream chat, and her interactions with Kaze were playful and personal, highlighting their casual dynamic.
zeina.quote: I will absolutely destroy you in bowling Zeina.

key_stories.title: The Emulator Problem
key_stories.summary: Faced with emulator instability and unhelpful community advice, Kaze switched to a private, in-development version of Project64. This 'Legacy' version provides the modern performance and stability he needs without forcing him to abandon the user interface he is most productive with.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's preferred emulator, Project64 1.6, was crashing, and he was frustrated with community suggestions for other emulators that didn't suit his development workflow.
key_stories.process: Instead of switching to a mainstream emulator he disliked, Kaze leveraged his connections or knowledge to obtain a private build that was tailored to advanced users, merging the old UI with a modern, more accurate backend.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now uses a private, in-development emulator called 'Project 64 Legacy' that solves the crashing and audio issues while keeping the interface he prefers, allowing him to work more effectively.
key_stories.key_quote: I have like a super top secret version. Basically, there is a project going on. That's called Project 64 Legacy. And they are using Project 64 1.6's UI. But they're importing new emulation features.

key_stories.title: Creating the Fireplace Asset
key_stories.summary: To improve the visuals of the mine level, Kaze decided to create a new fireplace asset. He sourced a model online, then used a multi-step process of decimation and UV unwrapping in Blender to make it suitable for the N64, resulting in a visually appealing prop with dynamic lighting.
key_stories.challenge: The mine level needed atmospheric light sources, but the existing fireplace asset was ugly and Kaze needed to create a new one that was both aesthetically pleasing and performant on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze found a suitable 3D model online, used Blender's decimate tool to lower its polygon count, manually cleaned up the UV texture map to fix rendering artifacts, and then integrated it into the level with custom lighting effects.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a new, optimized fireplace asset with dynamic lighting that significantly enhanced the visual atmosphere of the Goomba bandit camp area, expressing great satisfaction with the result.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, there we go, that is the fire I was looking for. That looks so good. Look at the light on Mario too. Oh yeah, that's what I'm talking about.

key_stories.title: Community-Sourced Optimization
key_stories.summary: During the stream, a viewer suggested a technical optimization for the game's collision system. Kaze immediately recognized the merit of the idea—switching from linked lists to arrays—and incorporated it into his development plan, showcasing a collaborative approach to engine improvement.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to decide on the underlying data structure for the game's collision system, with the current implementation potentially being suboptimal.
key_stories.process: A viewer in the chat suggested that using arrays for collision data, formed when a level loads, would be more performant than the current linked list system. Kaze evaluated the suggestion in real-time and agreed with its logic.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to adopt the suggestion and planned to implement it as a future performance tweak, demonstrating an openness to external technical feedback to improve the game's engine.
key_stories.key_quote: Your idea sounds sensible khaki honestly maybe there should just be arrays formed when the level boots you know what I'll note that changed on that's a good idea.
